Award.AwardTitle: Radiative Thermal Conductivity of Upper Mantle and Transition Zone Minerals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The structure and dynamics of our planet's interior depend crucially upon heat flow and thus upon the thermal conductivity of its constituents. Thermal conductivities of Earth's mantle materials, such as olivine, majorite, wadsleyite and ringwoodite, are important parameters for geodynamic models of mantle convection. Differences in radiative thermal conductivities of these minerals will affect models of lithospheric geotherms, subduction dynamics, and the structure of lithospheric slabs. However, there is a lack of experimental data about radiative thermal conductivities, especially at the high pressures and temperatures that exist in the deep interior. This experimental study aims to complement evolving theoretical frameworks, extend ongoing projects to all major constituents of the Earth's mantle, and indirectly measure the temperature-pressure variation of radiative thermal conductivity using in-situ optical spectroscopy. A primary goal of the project is to further our understanding of a major driving force of nature - heat flow within the Earth.

This project builds on recent in-situ optical measurements, in which two major transition zone phases, hydrous wadsleyite and hydrous ringwoodite, were studied for the first time at simultaneous high pressure and high temperature. The PI reported radiative thermal conductivities of 1.5 Wm-1K-1 for hydrous wadsleyite and 1.2 Wm-1K-1 for hydrous ringwoodite at transition zone conditions. For anhydrous wadsleyite and ringwoodite radiative conductivities were analytically derived to be 40% and 33% higher, respectively. The results indicate that the transition zone may contribute significantly to heat transfer in the mantle and demonstrate the importance of radiative heat transfer in controlling geodynamic processes. The current project is an extension of those measurements to study olivine, majorite, akimotoite and phase D. The effect of sample thickness and compositional changes (such as iron and water concentrations) on thermal conductivity properties of majorite, akimotoite, phase D and olivine and its high-pressure polymorphs ringwoodite and wadsleyite will be systematically investigated. The experiments are very timely, since theoretical models are in development and experimental data are needed to support such models. This research is of highly collaborative nature, and will take advantage of the expertise and facilities of laboratories across the nation, as well as internationally. This work will illuminate a fundamentally interdisciplinary topic of deep concern to a broad audience, including mineral physicists, seismologists, geodynamicist, geochemists, and planetary scientists. This study will provide a valuable learning experience for undergraduate students, as well as important data, which will contribute to our knowledge of heat transfer in the Earth and eventually lead to refined thermal models of the Earth's interior.

Intellectual Merit: 

This project focused on a fundamentally interdisciplinary topic of deep concern to a broad audience, including mineral physicists, seismologists, geodynamicist, geochemists, and planetary scientists. Our study contributed to our knowledge of heat transfer in the Earth’s interior by providing experimental data needed to improve geophysical models of heat flux in the Earth, which are in development. It built upon a recent study, in which the PI had undertaken the first in-situ simultaneous high-pressure and high-temperature optical measurements of hydrous wadsleyite and ringwoodite to derive values of radiative thermal conductivity. The results demonstrated the importance of radiative heat transfer in controlling processes in Earth’s mantle. In this very timely project, the measurements were extended to study different Earth’s mantle and transition minerals to explore the effect of compositional changes (iron, water concentrations) of the samples on their radiative thermal conductivities. This work was of highly collaborative nature. The PI took advantage of the expertise and facilities of a variety of laboratories across the nation, as well as internationally. High-pressure synthesis experiments were carried out in large volume presses. Synthetic material (olivine, majoritic garnet, wadsleyite, ringwoodite, phase D) was characterized using analytical and spectroscopic techniques including secondary mass spectrometry, microprobe analysis, and Mössbauer, UV-Vis-IR, Brillouin, and Raman spectroscopy.

Optical absorption measurements of majoritic garnet were carried out in resistively heated diamond-anvil cells at room conditions and at simultaneous high pressure and high temperature up to 1000 K. Data was used to calculate thermal radiative conductivites. The average thermal conductivity at transition zone conditions was determined to be <1 W/m/K. Thus, our resultsconfirm that majoritic garnet, one of the major phases in the Earth’s mantle transition zone, contributes to heat transfer in the Earth’s interior, which is in good agreement with earlier results for hydrous ringwoodite and wadsleyite.

We furthermore produced a linear wavenumber-dependent IR calibration for water quantification in minerals of the pyrope–majorite solid-solution series, which will result in more accurate estimations of the water content in natural and synthetic majoritic garnets. Wavenumber-dependent factors allow the conversion of published H2O concentrations that use the Paterson (1982) or Libowitzky and Rossman (1997) calibration curves. For a mean wavenumber of 3550 cm–1, the conversion factors are 1.54 and 2.26, respectively. Our work illustrates that using IR absorption values previously reported for garnet would lead to over- and underestimation (depending on the published values used) of water contents in the case of majoritic garnets.

Based on the improved knowledge of the equation of state of majoritic garnet, we hope to be able to reevaluate the composition (peridotitic versus basaltic component) of the mantle transition zone from new and forthcoming regional seismic studies emanating from NSF's Earthscope USArray.

UV–Vis–IR spectroscopy was also carried out on ringwoodite, wadsleyite, olivine, and phase D. Results are prepared for publication. A Python-implemented code has been made available for community use and was applied to calculate radiative thermal conductivities for bridgmanite and dense silicate glasses (Goncharov et al., 2015; Murakami et al., 2014).

We further report a linear wavenumber-dependent IR calibration for H2O quantification in hydrous ringwoodite across the Mg2SiO4-Fe2SiO4 solid solution series, which will lead to more accurate estimations of the water content in both laboratory-grown and naturally occurring ringwoodites.  Ringwoodite, gamma-(Mg,Fe)2SiO4, is stable in the lower 150 kilometers of the Earth’s mantle transition zone (410–660 km depth) and can incorporate up to 1.5–2 wt% H2O as hydroxyl point defects.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project provided valuable learning experiences for students. Undergraduate student Kathryn Wilson was supported by this grant and received training in sample preparation (including sample polishing, and the assembly of resistively heated diamond anvil cells), X-ray diffraction and microprobe analyses, and was also involved in data analyses (data fitting, plotting, Python calculations) and publication preparation. She polished synthesized single-crystals to prepare them for Raman and UV-Vis-IR analyses. She also prepared sample mounts for microprobe and SIMS analyses, and assisted in microprobe analyses of the synthesized material at UNLV. Steven Jacobsen's graduate student John Lazarz at Northwestern University was involved in this project. He investigated the high PT equation of state of majoritic garnet using Brillouin spectroscopy and carried out high-precision lattice parameter measurements and structure refinements on synthesized majorite crystals using single-crystal X-ray diffraction. 

Results have been summarized in 4 conference papers and presented at national and international meetings, the AGU fall meetings 2012, 2013, and 2014; 2 more conference contributions have been made in 2015 (Goldschmidt conference in Prague, AGU Fall meeting). Six manuscripts summarizing the results have been published. More publications are in preparation.
